metadata./Title: Simultaneous central retinal vein and cilioretinal artery occlusion in a young female patient with progestin-only oral contraceptive use: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Central retinal vein occlusion and cilioretinal artery occlusion are rare but serious ocular conditions that can lead to significant visual impairment. While few cases of central retinal vein occlusion and cilioretinal 
artery occlusion have been individually reported, concurrent occlusion of both vessels is extremely rare, particularly 
in younger patients without traditional vascular risk factors. We present the first reported case of simultaneous central 
retinal vein occlusion and cilioretinal artery occlusion in a young female patient associated with short-term use 
of progestin-only oral contraceptives (OCPs).
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 28-year-old Pakistani female patient presented with sudden, painless vision loss in the left 
eye, 3 hours prior to her arrival at the ophthalmology clinic. Visual acuity in the affected eye was limited to counting 
fingers at a distance of 0.5 feet, with a best-corrected visual acuity of 6/6 in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination 
revealed optic disc edema, preretinal hemorrhages, venous dilation, and cotton wool spots consistent with central 
retinal vein occlusion, alongside ischemic changes in the foveal region suggestive of cilioretinal artery occlusion. 
On the basis of clinical examination, fundus fluorescein angiography, and optical coherence tomography findings, 
the patient was diagnosed with concurrent central retinal vein occlusion and cilioretinal artery occlusion. Systemic 
workup to rule out thrombophilia and other vascular risks was negative. She was treated with acetazolamide, aspirin, 
and ocular massage, alongside a dorzolamide-timolol combination for intraocular pressure control. Six weeks later, 
panretinal photocoagulation was performed to prevent neovascular complications.
Conclusions This case highlights the rare presentation of simultaneous central retinal vein occlusion and cilioretinal 
artery occlusion, likely precipitated by short-term progestin-only OCP use in a young female. The absence of other 
vascular risk factors emphasizes the potential thrombotic risk associated with hormonal contraception, even in brief 
courses. Careful consideration should be given to contraceptive choice, and ophthalmologic monitoring is recommended for early detection and intervention in at-risk patients.

Background
Cilioretinal artery occlusion (CLRAO) and central 
retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) are serious ocular con ditions characterized by the partial or complete block age of the cilioretinal artery and central retinal vein, 
respectively [1 , 2]. Common risk factors for vascular 
occlusions include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, 
obesity, and arteriosclerosis. Other contributors, such 
as vascular damage, hypercoagulability, thrombosis, 
and cardiovascular disease, further elevate the risk. 
In rare instances, retinal vessel occlusions have been 
attributed to oral contraceptive use [3 ] The combined 
oral contraceptives (COCs) contain both estrogen 
and progesterone, and work by inhibiting ovulation 
through negative feedback on the hypothalamic–pitui tary axis, thickening cervical mucosa to prevent sperm 
from entering the uterus, and inhibiting the growth 
of the endometrium. However, progestin-only pills, 
also known as mini-pills, only contain progesterone 
and they change the thickening of the cervical mucus 
to prevent the entrance of sperm. In younger women, 
the use of low-dose COCs can have detrimental effects 
on bone mineral density and may increase the risk of 
venous thrombosis [4 ]. Progestin-only pills are rec ommended for breastfeeding women or those who 
experience side effects, such as nausea, from estro gen [4 ]. The development of ocular complications is 
rare in women receiving oral contraceptives, that is, 
1 in 230,000. Ophthalmologic complications such as 
dry eyes, corneal disturbances, lens opacities, vascular 
occlusions, and neuro-ophthalmological complications 
correlate with the expression of progesterone receptors 
in the ocular tissues [5 ]. Among ocular complications, 
central retinal vein and cilioretinal artery occlusions 
are exceedingly rare and are considered as ophthal mologic emergencies requiring prompt diagnosis and 
intervention. Typically, retinal vessel occlusions are 
more common in the elderly, and their occurrence in 
younger patients is rarely reported in the literature 
[4]. Patients with retinal vessel occlusions often pre sent with a sudden onset of symptoms such as blurred 
vision, headache, and vision loss in one eye, which may 
worsen with time if untreated. Complicated cases also 
present with retinal hemorrhage and swelling, leading 
to permanent vision loss.
In this case study, we report a unique instance of 
concurrent central retinal vein and cilioretinal artery 
occlusion in a 28-year-old female patient with a history 
of progestin-only contraceptive use. This report con tributes valuable insights to the limited literature on 
retinal vascular complications in younger populations.Case presentation
A 28-year-old Pakistani female patient presented to the 
ophthalmology department of Jinnah Hospital Lahore, 
with a 3 hour history of sudden, painless loss of vision in 
the left eye. The onset was abrupt, with no prior episodes 
of similar symptoms. The patient did not report any asso ciated symptoms such as ocular redness, discharge, diz ziness, headache, or blackouts. Additionally, she denied 
any history of photopsia (flashes of light) or vitreous 
floaters.
The patient is a mother of three children who under went a cesarean section (C-section) for each delivery; 
her most recent C-section was 3.5  months ago. She 
experienced normal mobility postoperatively, with no 
complaints of pain, bleeding, or sleep disturbances. She 
breastfed all of her children. After her last delivery, she 
started taking progestin-only pills for contraception, 
which she took for 25  days before discontinuing. Upon 
systemic review, the patient did not provide any pertinent 
history related to her current presentation. Her personal 
and family history were negative for congenital abnor malities or bleeding disorders. Additionally, there was no 
history of smoking, previous contraceptive use, diabetes, 
or hypertension.
The initial ophthalmic examination demonstrated a 
best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of 6/6 in the right 
eye and counting fingers (CF) at a distance of 0.5 feet 
in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was recorded at 
12  mmHg in both eyes. Examination of the left eye 
revealed a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). 
The patient displayed full extraocular movements in 
both eyes. Anterior segment evaluation of the left eye 
was unremarkable. However, dilated fundus examina tion revealed findings indicative of central retinal vein 
occlusion (CRVO), including optic disc edema, 360 
degrees of preretinal hemorrhages, venous dilation 
and tortuosity, and cotton wool spots. Furthermore, a

white ischemic area was observed nasally to the fovea, 
suggestive of a possible ciliary retinal artery occlusion 
(Fig. 1 ).
Additionally, anterior and posterior segment exami nations were conducted for the right eye, and the find ings were unremarkable and within normal limits. 
Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed inner 
retinal hyperreflectivity (Fig. 2 ).
Furthermore, fluorescein fundus angiography (FFA) 
revealed delayed dye filling of the ciliary retinal artery, 
with a masking effect due to preretinal hemorrhages 
in the left eye. Systemic investigations were under taken and all of her workup was within normal lim its. On the basis of these findings, she was clinically 
diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) 
accompanied by ciliary retinal artery (CLRA) occlusion 
secondary to OCPs. The patient was given acetazola mide, aspirin, ocular massage, and a combination of 
dorzolamide and timolol. She was monitored biweekly 
to assess visual acuity and intraocular pressure (IOP) 
for 12  weeks, followed by evaluations every 8  weeks 
for 6 months, then biannual check-ups for 2 years. At 
6 weeks, after resolution of the preretinal hemorrhages, 
panretinal photocoagulation was performed to prevent 
neovascular glaucoma, which is associated with central 
retinal vein occlusion within 90 days. It was performed 
prophylactically as the patient resides in a remote area 
and was unwilling to adhere to a regular follow-up 
schedule. Intravitreal antivascular endothelial growth 
factor (VEGF) was not used, as no macular edema was 
observed on OCT. By the 12th week, the patient’s vision 
was 6/36, with an IOP of 12 mmHg in the left eye.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusions
Simultaneous central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) and 
cilioretinal vein occlusion (CLRAO) is an uncommon 
occurrence, especially in young adults. CRVO typically
sections.Results:
results from blockage in the central retinal vein, leading 
to venous stasis, retinal ischemia, and subsequent com plications such as macular edema and neovasculariza tion. CLRAO, however, involves occlusion of cilioretinal 
artery, a vessel supplying blood to the retina, often lead ing to sudden vision loss in the affected eye [1].
The incidence of CRVO is about 1.9 per 100,000, 
whereas CLRAO is a rare retinal vascular event, account ing for only 5.3–7.1% of all retinal artery occlusions [4]. 
In this case, the patient had nonarteritic CLRAO sub type, as classified by Brown et al. [6], occurring in asso ciation with CRVO. The presence of both conditions is 
suggestive of vascular damage precipitated by an external 
factor, such as oral contraceptive use, in the absence of 
any systemic risk factors.
The patient’s recent history of progestin-only OCP 
use was particularly relevant, as these oral contracep tives have been associated with increased risks of venous 
thrombosis (VTE), with combined oral contraceptives 
increasing the risk 2–3-fold [7]. Cockrum et al. concluded 
that progestin, particularly in higher doses or formula tions such as norethindrone acetate and medroxypro gesterone acetate, has been associated with higher odds 
of acute VTE [8]. Although the incidence of ocular vas cular complications from progestin-only pills is exceed ingly low (1 in 230,000). In this case, the patient had been 
using 5  mg progestin-only pills once a day for 25  days 
before discontinuing, which may have contributed to the 
development of these simultaneous occlusions.
The patient underwent thorough systemic and ophthal mologic evaluations to rule out other potential causes. 
Investigations for congenital and acquired thrombophilia, 
such as prothrombin time (PT), activated partial throm boplastin time (APTT), international normalized ratio 
(INR), antiphospholipid antibodies, and factor V Leiden 
mutation yielded normal results. The patient also did not 
have other common risk factors such as diabetes, hyper lipidemia, or autoimmune conditions. Her autoimmune 
profile was normal. No plaque or thrombus was noted 
on carotid Doppler ultrasonography. Echocardiography 
was also unremarkable. Abdominal and pelvic ultrasound 
reports were unremarkable. No sign of retinal vascular 
inflammation was noted on slit lamp biomicroscopy.
Given the dual nature of the occlusions, the treatment 
aimed to address both CRVO and CLRAO. The patient 
was prescribed acetazolamide, aspirin, and ocular mas sage, followed by dorzolamide–timolol combination ther apy. Panretinal photocoagulation was performed 6 weeks 
after the initial presentation to prevent the development

of neovascular glaucoma, a common complication asso ciated with CRVO. However, intravitreal anti-VEGF was 
not administered since the patient did not exhibit mac ular edema, which is a frequent complication of CRVO. 
Despite the timely intervention, the patient’s visual out come was modest, with final visual acuity of 6/36 in the 
affected eye by the 12th week of follow-up. At her last 
follow-up, 4 months postprocedure, the retina remained 
stable with no signs of neovascularization at the disc 
(NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE). Panreti nal photocoagulation laser (PRP) laser marks were visible 
in a 360-degree pattern, with no recurrence of ischemia 
or hemorrhage observed. This reflects the complexity of 
managing concurrent retinal vein and artery occlusions. 
The involvement of both vessels is more likely to com pound the visual impairment. From a clinical perspective, 
this case highlights the need for cautious use of hormonal 
contraceptives, particularly in young women with other 
potential thrombotic risk factors. Although the patient in 
this case had no prior history of conditions such as diabe tes or hypertension, the use of progestin-only OCPs led 
to vessel occlusions. Patients who continue to use hor monal contraception exhibit findings indicative of early 
retinal vascular stress such as microaneurysms, small ret inal hemorrhages, arteriolar narrowing, or mild venous 
dilation. The use of alternative, nonhormonal contra ceptive
sections.Methods:
methods should be considered in patients with a 
history of vascular events or in those at elevated risk for 
thrombotic complications. This patient was referred to a 
gynecologist who advised her to discontinue progestinonly pills. Furthermore, patients who continue to use 
hormonal contraception should be regularly examined 
for early detection of vascular changes.
This case highlights the rare occurrence of combined 
CRVO and CLRAO in a young female patient following 
the short-term use of progestin-only oral contracep tives. The absence of any systemic risk factors, along 
with a negative systemic workup, suggested the use of 
the oral contraceptive as a precipitating factor for the 
vascular occlusions. There is limited literature on reti nal vessel occlusions associated with oral contraceptive 
use. Previously, cases of central retinal vein occlusion 
[9] and cilioretinal artery occlusion [10] associated 
with oral contraceptives have been reported indepen dently. However, this is the first documented case of 
concurrent central retinal vein and cilioretinal artery 
occlusion occurring simultaneously following oral con traceptive use.
